column3: in the summer holidays when I reluctantly tore myself away from the task of doing nothing in particular
column4: and put on a hat of some sort and picked up a walking-stick
column5: and put six very bright-coloured chalks in my pocket. I then went into the kitchen (which
column6: along with the rest of the house
column7: belonged to a very square and sensible old woman in a Sussex village)
column8: and asked the owner and occupant of the kitchen if she had any brown paper. She had a great deal; in fact
column9: she had too much; and she mistook the purpose and the rationale of the existence of brown paper. She seemed to have an idea that if a person wanted brown paper he must be wanting to tie up parcels; which was the last thing I wanted to do; indeed
column10: it is a thing which I have found to be beyond my mental capacity.
